VALUE: The bottom line is you better have a really good rate if youâ€™re gonna stay here and be happy about it, unless of course youâ€™ve got business at the Rogers Center. Hit up Hotwire or Priceline for this property, but cross your fingers you get one of the other four star hotels in downtown Toronto.

Reviews.Title: “A good deal”
Reviews.Author: travelingcouple03
Reviews.Content: We stayed for two nights at the Renaissance Toronto Hotel while attending functions in the city and doing some shopping. The Front entrance to the hotel - attached to the Roger's Centre Dome - is not the most user friendly. The front desk area is very open and right by the front door, where people tend to hang about. The parking is not the easiest to find, infact they give you a map and directions. Front desk staff was friendly and knowledgable. We asked for a quiet room on a higher floor which we were given. The room was fine; clean and spacious. I checked out the bathroom and bed immediately and found both clean. The decor is typical of the Mariott style - neutral colours and basic amenities. I reviewed previous entries on this hotel before booking, and I was fortunate not to have had a bad experience, however i can see how if there is an event at the Rogers Centre, the entire feeling and mood of the hotel would be very different. This hotel is would be a huge attraction for groups attending sporting or music events, which would spill back into the hotel at late hours. The price is very reasonable for a downtown hotel. We had friends staying at neighbouring hotels who had much smaller rooms, noisy and paid double what we did. We went and checked out the pool and the fitness facility. The pool is large and clean. The fitness room is now housed in a small meeting room. The very large fitness centre which is attached to the hotel appears to have gone out of business. You could see into it from the pool area, but it was in darkness and no one around. A few basic cardio machines were set up in the make shift "fitness room" for guest use. Over all, it is a good moderate hotel. Do not expect opulance or frills, but it is clean and decent.

Reviews.Title: “Agreed with many other travellers, average hotel”
Reviews.Author: PMartin148
Reviews.Content: Came to TO for a mini vacation with husband to see Star Wars in concert. Front valet was helpful finding the self parking (wouldnt have been able too without him). Hotel lobby and hallways had a funny smell to it in the morning. Others were correct pool is terrible, the roof was in disrepair and the workout club which both the pool and the work out club is an attached area (open to the public) was closed. They had a make due workout room in the lobby part of the pool area. The rooms were only satisfactory with no fan in the bathroom. The shower had stains on the marble. And the whole place needs a face lift. But the rooms were clean and the people were nice. The lobby bar was crouded with conference people (again like someone else said eww). If you are looking for a 4 star hotel this is not one anymore, at most this is a 3 star at best. We only took this place as Price line has great deals for "chopping prices in half" and we got a deal of 75$ for the room. But this place is way overpriced for what we wold have paid had we not done that.

Reviews.Title: “Averagely average. You can do better than this.”
Reviews.Author: unclejames
Reviews.Content: I keep making a silly mistake: and that's to occasionally book a chain hotel such as this one. It's part of the Marriott group, and has the same boring lack of any individuality that plagues big hotel chains. The hotel room itself was nice: I got a suite, by accident. The hotel gives you some water ($5 if opened), some coffee (we have provided two sachets, and housekeeping can arrange for more if required), a couple of big televisions (Rogers' bizarrely-organised standard station list, and a pay-movie option), toiletries that appeared to be magically thrown together from three different brands. And high-speed internet for 'only' $12.95 a day. When I got there, the place was full of conference suits taking a cigarette-break outside. When I left, the bar was standing-room-only of conference suits 'networking'. Shudder. The staff were average, with the doorman only bothering to open one door for me, leaving me to struggle through the other with my bag. The desk staff didn't ask whether I had a good stay or otherwise appear to care about me. It's probably fine for someone who hates any form of individuality in a hotel. Probably fine for someone who wants their hotel room to be exactly the same whether they're in Toronto or Tokyo. But not for me. I've not scored this hotel even an average score: because any hotel that still charges for internet access automatically loses a point, regardless of how good it is. And this is not a good hotel. It's just average. Staying in Toronto? You can do so much better.

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel - except for fitness/pool”
Reviews.Author: NYCandworld
Reviews.Content: I had a nice weekend stay at this property. The room was the highlight. It was spacious and extremely clean. Other areas of the hotel felt a bit dated. The pool and fitness center were very low quality and not up to typical Marriott standard. The location was good - just a little bit off the beaten path for exploring the center of toronto but close to CN Tower, and not far from Queen St. Overall, I would recommend.

Reviews.Title: “clean, comfortable, good location, pool not great”
Reviews.Author: Beancounter4
Reviews.Content: My son and I stayed here in August. The hotel is very convenient to everything downtown. We walked from Union Station to the hotel and then later walked to all the downtown attractions. I asked for early arrival as our train was arriving before check in time. Room was not ready when we arrived but we had lunch and came back and reception was eager to get us into a room as quickly as possible. The rooms were huge, beds were among the most comfortable I've ever slept in. We had a $40 food voucher given to us upon check in, so we used it for room service for breakfast. The food was more than adequate and compared to room services prices elsewhere, it was not outlandish. Very quick service. The pool area is shared with an unaffiliated gym. It was just a regular pool, not very big and not any extra neat stuff for the kids. There was a hot tub, but it foamed up so full of soap or ? that we didn't stay in. Overall, the price was good, location was great and the rooms were very nice. We would return again.

Reviews.Title: “Weekend conference in Toronto”
Reviews.Author: JMD_from_Montreal
Reviews.Content: This is a pretty good hotel. I stayed at this hotel during a 2 day continuing education course. The course organizers selected the hotel and presumably obtained a group rate, so I cannot say how much the room costs. I flew into Toronto quite late and arrived at ~1 am. The receptionist at the front desk was helpful, and I believe, provided me an "upgraded" room. The room is very nice. It was a two floor room, with a view on the Rogers Centre field. I am not much of a spectator sports fan, but can easily imagine the appeal in watching the Blue Jays (or Argonauts) put up a valiant struggle before eventual defeat... The lower room has a capacity limit of 15. The bedroom upstairs was well furnished. The upstairs wash-room had a complicated shower with too many levers and buttons. A comfortable king-sized bed was provided. A coffee machine is provided. The rooms are non-smoking. The hotel has a somewhat dated feel, I suspect reflective of the decade in which the Rogers centre (former Sky Dome) was built. Clean, but starting to be a little worn out. The conference facilities were good individually. Getting from one meeting room to another was an exercise in trail making. A large auditorium is on the 2nd floor (with nice views of the city) and two meeting rooms in the basement. This required 2 elevators or 3 sets of fire-escape style stairs. The food during the breaks was typical (not too healthy muffins mostly). A few significant down-sides: 1 Transit to the hotel almost certainly requires a taxi ride. I took the TTC from the Airport to the hotel when I arrived, but this is a long time-consuming ride, 1 bus, 2 subways and a 5-6 block walk from Union station. Going back to the hotel, I took a taxi (but keep in mind the inevitable traffic to the airport and count 60 - 90 minutes in travel). 2 An exercise centre is provided, but closed as of 6pm on Saturday and all day Sunday, so entirely useless for my needs. (Very contradictory for a "sports" themed hotel.) 3 Religious propaganda is in full place at this hotel, not only the typical hotel bible but also a mormon religious text is available for your reading pleasure! 4 Finally, Internet access is available (wireless or wired)... at a cost of $13 / day. I find this excessive and clearly priced above the cost of the providing service. At a hotel that does not charge for using the TV, hot water or electricity, I believe that $13 (plus tax) is a rip-off. Overall, I would recommend the hotel (with reservations), especially for someone who enjoys spectator sports.

Reviews.Title: “When Priceline Attacks!”
Reviews.Author: GroceryLawyer
Reviews.Content: Full disclosure, I got a ridiculously good Priceline bid in ($61/night), so I'm really not complaining. But beware, as Priceline says this is a 4-star hotel - there's just no way that it is. While I'm sure I wasn't going to be given the Rain Man Suite based upon my Priceline bid, would it have been asking too much to get a room that didn't have its (dated) wallpaper falling off or one that had all the trash picked up from the floor before we got there? Decor for the hotel is super old and in need of updating. Also, if you get an outside room, be aware the train runs right next to it. To be fair, the windows were pretty sound proof, so it just sounded like a dog growling when the train when by. The soundproofing between the hallways and the room, however, is a different story - you hear every yahoo coming back at 2:00 am and later. Romance factor is a zero. Location is just ok - right accross from CN Tower, which is good if you're going to the CN Tower, but a 10 minute walk to the nearest subway station (Union) where you can reach more of the action (Toronto has a lot of great things to do, and the subway is a nice way to get to them). That walk was not fun in the rain. In summary, this is by no means a terrible place, it just is not the kind of place you want to pay rack rates for, and not the 4 star that Priceline says it is.

Reviews.Title: “Great service & location, but maybe a little worn”
Reviews.Author: PlannermanNL
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this hotel two times on our recent vacation - one night at the beginning and two nights at the end. Our party included two adults, one preschooler and one teenager. On our first night we had an excellent room on the eighth floor that was well worth every penny - lots of room and well laid out. Unfortunately there weren't any stadium view rooms available. On our return to the hotel a few days later we were given another room on the eighth but it was very poorly laid out and way smaller than the first. It wasn't good for us at all, but we got moved after discovering that one section of the carpeting on the floor was soaking wet - a leak from the pipes in the washrrom I suspect! The room on the 3rd floor that we got moved to was adequate, and probably a little above average with respect to room size, but certainly not as well laid out as our first room. Overall, the hotel was good, and the service was great, but parts of the hotel was looking a little worn. Maybe some minor renos might help some areas of the decor! Parking: $20 per day is a pretty good rate, and I would advise against valet parking. The entrance to the underground parking is a few minutes drive away, but the parking is directly underneath the hotel so it is an easy jaunt to the elevators and into the hotel. Room Service: Very slow and extremely salty for our tastes. Priced about average for room service. Restaurant: The weekend buffet was quite good and not priced too high. Kids under five get the buffet for free, but be sure to check your bill - we were charged for our preschooler, but this was quickly fixed when it was brought to the attention of the staff. Service: Excellent. All of the staff that we encountered were excellent - very friendly and helpful.

Reviews.Title: “Awesome, especially if you are a baseball fan!”
Reviews.Author: tadala
Reviews.Content: I visited Toronto with a bunch of buddies who do a yearly baseball trip. We stayed at the Renaissance because it was connected to the Skydome (Rogers Center). I must say from the moment I walked in and saw the lobby and lounge area I fell in love with this hotel. There is no other place that you can be in the lounge of your hotel and overlook a major league baseball game. You can come in and have a beer or two and take in some of the best scenery anywhere. Even when the game is not going on the lights to the Rogers Center are on and there always seems to be something going on. As for the rooms, I thought they were just fine. A comfortable bed with a nice bathroom and clean. The windows were large but needed to be washed. The location is second to none anyhwere in the city. We walked everywhere we need to go. Plenty of nightlife, restaurants and shopping close by. We stayed on the fifth floor where the walk to your room was like a maze but I did not mind at all because ti was so unique. We did catch a peek at the rooms that overlooked the stadium, the windows so open so you can hear the action. We did have the brunch one day, it was just OK. Bring your wallets when you go to Toronto, it is quite costly! I would stay here again, the hotel is very cool and not outdated at all as some reviews mention. The pool and fitness center were the best I have ever seen for a full service hotel not considering themselves as a spa or resort.

Reviews.Title: “Right in the Heart of Touristy Activity.”
Reviews.Author: dgreene13
Reviews.Content: This hotel is clean and the front desk staff friendly and helpful. It is attached to the Rogers Centre (Sky Dome), and is right next to CN Tower, Union Station, Steam Whistle Brewery and a bridge away from the Path. We were upgraded (free) to a king suite, but the room was a long walk from the desk area. Fortunately, we were able to use the fire exit to arrive at the outside entrance to the right field entrance to the stadium and locations stated above. At $139 per night, I thought a bit pricey. Self Parking was $20/night and they charge for internet

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel - Great Location”
Reviews.Author: piernikm
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this hotel for a weekender in Toronto. I wanted to stay somewhere within walking distance to major attractions. The hotel is connected to the Rogers Center, and right next door to the CN Tower. It's a $12 cab ride to Medieval Times / HarbourFronte, and walking distance to Kings St (many great bars and restaurants). We arrived early, but were able to check right in (at noon!!). Our room had a view of the stadium, and they were setting up for the Jonas Bro's concert! We were able to open the window & see the entire stadium. The hotel pool area was clean and nice! There's a hot tub, huge fitness center, and sauna. Towels are provided. The only confusing this about this hotel is parking, which is behind the Rogers Center and across the street. The king size bed was the most comfortable bed I've ever slept in! And the 8 accompaning down pillows helped add to the comfort. Great hotel, great value, great location. I would go back in a heartbeat!

Reviews.Title: “excellent hotel”
Reviews.Author: DRTYA
Reviews.Content: This is our second stay here, and both were just perfect. This time we got the room with 2 double beds and it was more like a suite, a huge room with an attached living room. Staff were very nice, breakfast very good, and the location superb. Only problem were the old small TVs( 2 in the room though). Would love to stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Nice pool, but no four star hotel”
Reviews.Author: JMOsaka
Reviews.Content: If you're going for the baseball it's probably a great hotel for a great price. Otherwise, there are many better four star hotels in Toronto. This place is older, grungy, and being at Skydome is actually a bit of a hike from the center of the city. The pool was nice but I wouldn't choose this place again.

Reviews.Title: “Cold Front desk- best for baseball fans”
Reviews.Author: witz
Reviews.Content: We found the front desk staff to be highly impersonal and very unhelpful when we tried to check in early at 2pm and then at 4 and then at 5, etc, etc.. There's nothing warm about the hotel except for the bar that looks out to the Roger's centre stadium which makes for s nice place for drinks and quick get-togethers. Plus we disliked not having the free internet in the bedrooms--how long will you hang out in the lobby? We will go elsewhere for our next Toronto trip

Reviews.Title: “Good for access to Rogers Centre but fairly average.”
Reviews.Author: reclermo
Reviews.Content: The Renaissance hotel is a decent option for those visiting the Rogers Centre for an event, but is a little too far out of the way to access a lot of restaurants and shopping on foot. The hotel was comfortable; however, is in need of a facelift to bring it up to date with the standards set by other 4 star competitors in Toronto. The valet service was very good and the team was always very helpful and accomodating. Overall, we thought that the hotel was fairly average, but could do with some updated improvements. Currently, I would say that the hotel should be classed as a 3 star property.

Reviews.Title: “Great location”
Reviews.Author: jen2RochesterNy
Reviews.Content: We've stayed here before but it was in the winter time. This time it was so warm it was no problem walking. Was much closer to things than I thought it would be. We like to walk alot so we went everywhere from chinatown, up close to bloor, to st. lawrence market.. I didnt even check the pool as last time it was cold and the pool area was pretty dingy. Our room was very nice- overlooked the railroad tracks as they all do. The size of the room was fine for us, the bathroom was HUGE, it was like a public restroom! Overall, our stay was very nice, especially for the price we paid through priceline. The one negative for us was the bed- it was terribly uncomfortable- we've stayed at loads of hotels in toronto before and all seem to have very nice beds, these were very hard and the odd shaped square pillows made it hard to get comfortable. For our first weekend away from kids in a very long time we expected a good nights sleep which we definately did not get.

Reviews.Title: “This hotel is manned by the rudest staff!”
Reviews.Author: norento
Reviews.Content: Having been billed on my VISA for more than twice the amount of my "Final bill" left under my door, I was then rudely interrupted on the phone by the sales manager while I tried to explain this fact and told that the hotel would not refund my money. Also, we experienced very incompetent staff at the desk. (Our room was not ready at 4:30 of the day of check-in, and we had 3 babies with us! No one had noted on our reservation that we needed cribs, although I had called 3 times to verify that, etc.)

Reviews.Title: “A Good Hotel If You Get A Good Rate”
Reviews.Author: jimmyschippy
Reviews.Content: Spent three nights at this hotel and we were extremely pleased with the standard of the hotel. I've stayed at most of the different Marriott brands but this was my first time in the Renaissance chain. The room had a lot of modern conveniences, an extremely comfortable bed and a luxurious bathroom with plenty of towels and rather nice toiletries. The location is ideal for the Entertainment District and a five minute walk to the nearest Subway Station and although the rooms mostly face onto the rather busy rail tracks the rooms are soundproof. For those interested in leisure facilities the pool area sports a jacuzzi and sauna and the gym is well stocked with modern equipment (according to my better half). There are one or two niggles. Internet for non-laptop holders is expensive and having to pay for coffee in the lobby at breakfast seems a bit cheap and I personally found the lobby area and entrance a bit underwhelming. We got a great rate booking directly through Marriott but I think I'd be reluctant to pay the extra dollars for the full rate, I'd rather pay an equivalent price and stay at the Residence which is just across the street and has superior rooms and breakfast included.

Reviews.Title: “Good Location”
Reviews.Author: sgmkjsekar
Reviews.Content: Recently, we stayed for a night in Renaissance and we got a decent offer directly from marriott website. The room is great, comfortable enough for a couple. The hotel is in the heart of the downtown, all attractions are nearby. From the restaurant, the hotel offers a good view of the Rogers Skydome and the hotel was crowded since there was a match on the day. The only thing which we didn't like is there was no complimentary items. Everything is charged right from Water bottle (costs $4.5), Parking ($20), Internet ($15).. For the money we are paying, these stuff should be offered free. Overall, it's a nice stay but there may be hotels around which would offer many complimentary stuff for the same charge..

Reviews.Title: “Good deal”
Reviews.Author: Janie_pooh
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Renaissance while in town for a Bat Mitzfah. We booked through Priceline and got an amazing deal and even got a room upgrade at check-in. The jacuzzi was nice and the room was very big. Service was good as well. That said, I don't think it is a four star hotel, more like a nice three and a half star. I would say stay there if you can get a good deal.

Reviews.Title: “Great Location”
Reviews.Author: Taralynne
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this hotel at the end of March for a girls weekend. The room was large and clean and in great location to walk to the CN tower and ACC. We had a discount room price or it may have been to expensive. Would stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Great Package offers”
Reviews.Author: judestravell
Reviews.Content: Stayed 2 nights - both packages booked separately - 1 adult with 2 children under 10 - Disney on Ice Package which included great seats at show with $88 food credit (and kids under 12 were free for breaky) - total pkg less tax was 282 less the food credit less the Disney tickets - so for our 1st night accomodation was $59 - booked the second night on separate package for $209 with CN tower tickets at $70 (only 2 adults) and $48 food credit which worked out to $91 for second night stay....you don't have to book packages for 2 nights - you can book adjoining packages but there may be hiccups... i.e. you have to re-checkin for each package and 'maybe' keep the same room. no biggie for the ultimate price. Hotel room 429 - very large room - cityview (kind of) - clean - not really dated - the usual hotel fair but a step above in overall accomodation - great beds, bath area and amenities, clean, good value for what we paid Restaurant and food - great staff, accomodating, child friendly, great prices for child menu even if not included, tasty food, good ambience, breakfast buffet good and staff go out of their way to please Pool - good for kids - if nonswimmers bring water wings/supports - 1/2 metres deep - very chorlinated and a bit aged but not bad - no towels for people in change rooms for pools or showering after..... Location - right beside CN Tower and Rogers Centre - great locale - not much walking anywhere to either - Hotel Customer Service - first impression - 2 star - the lady just didn't really care or want to be there - after that - all regular service personnel exceeded my expectations. Tried to call guest services and concierge who were not available plus on trying to seek info originally their is no 'sales personnel' available to help book packages on the weekend and forget trying to talk to the 1-800 people in the US - useless......However I met and dealt with several ladies at the front desk that did make things happen - got the 3 tickets to Disney and delivered personally to us - checked us in on the second package to the same room and got the CN package tickets for us. Would definitely recommend this hotel for clients especially for events/packages offered in this area of Toronto.

Reviews.Title: “This is where I stay when in Toronto on business”
Reviews.Author: cuberican
Reviews.Content: I always try to stay at this hotel. Very nice, quiet hotel. Great restaurant, although it's expensive. I usually upgrade and pay extra for the Concierge level, so that I can get free breakfast and snacks. The location is very close to the airport and easy freeway access to my customers. I generally stay at Marriott hotels and have stayed at the Courtyard and Marriott at the airport, but I like this hotel the best.

Reviews.Title: “Traveler beware!”
Reviews.Author: atourist00
Reviews.Content: First, this is a laughable "four star", as some travel booking sites classify this hotel. It's showing its age, there is no minibar or hotel safe in your room, services from other 4-star hotels are noticeably missing (turn-down, ice brought up to room, water, etc.) Good things = location (for Rogers center games, close to CN Tower, etc.), free Internet in lobby, bar looking field is very cool, friendly staff, probably the best workout and weight rooms with dozens of machines and free/machine weights (amazing facility but the rooms are a bit run down... who cares, you're there to work out and there's plenty of equipment.) Bad things = location (yep, it's farther from transport and other areas, slightly more north hotels are more desirable), fee Internet in room, no safe/minibar/free water, hotel is just not in the big leagues. It's like a run down Marriott. Bottom line = you should book this hotel if you can get the room for <$60. However, on Priceline it's a 4-star, so I got somewhat jacked (paid $88, not including the extra fees, so it wasn't worth it in my opinion.) Of course, if the Blue Jays are playing and you can get a room facing the field, it's totally worth it...

Reviews.Title: “Staff attitude and service made the difference”
Reviews.Author: Grenouillesansleau
Reviews.Content: Our flight to Newark was cancelled and the earliest flight we could get a confirmed booking for was 2 days later, so we headed downtown and decided to try a different Marriott for a night or two. (We had just checked out of the Residence Inn and were concerned that if we checked back in again, the 2nd stay wouldn't be counted for purposes of Marriott's promotion.) Initially, we were unimpressed. We arrived about 3:30 and the woman at the front desk told us no rooms were available yet. She did say she'd put a rush on the request to have a room cleaned and indicated we could wait in the lobby, where we could tell that at least one other couple was waiting. We waited for about 30 minutes and then I checked again with the same employee. Nothing. I asked if she could come over (i.e. walk about 20 feet) and let us know when the room was ready. She said no because the only way she'd know the room was ready was by checking the computer, so we'd just have to keep coming back and asking her. (Obviously, she could have initiated the query herself and then come and told us, but she couldn't be bothered.) About 15 minutes later, my husband went and asked the other front desk employee (Ryan), who checked and said that the room wasn't ready yet but took the initiative to give us a coupon for two free drinks and an appetizer at the restaurant. A few minutes later, he jogged over to the restaurant (so, clearly, front desk employees aren't glued to the floor) with the keys and said he'd checked and the room was now ready, and yes, we could still use the coupon. He was all smiles and initiative, in marked contrast to his colleague. We went up to the room, but were disappointed to discover that it (1037) ran along behind the elevator bank, with the bed up against the wall where the elevators run. I'm not too picky about my room, but one thing I hate is being near the elevator. So we called the desk and reached the not-very-helpful woman I'd first dealt with. When I asked if another room was available, she said no but that we certainly could come back downstairs, wait again and see if something else opened up. Her choice of words was perfectly polite and professional but her tone of voice clearly conveyed the impression that she thought we were demaning too much and that she'd rather do something other than help us. Back downstairs, we made a beeline for Ryan, who queried the system and told us that a few rooms had opened up in the meantime. He then recommended a room that he characterized as "one of his favourites", explaining that although it was on the other side of the other elevators, the layout was such that the bed was far from the elevator and that the room had other nice features. We checked it out and he was right. It might have been just a sales pitch, but he delivered it with such sincerity and demonstrated so clearly throughout the rest of our visit that he wanted to go the extra mile to make our stay pleasant that he completely changed our initial, less than favourable impression of the hotel. The new room, 1135, was a little noisy (due more to the trains outside), but we found it was large and comfortable. At $120 per night (with a good, free breakfast included because I have gold status), the hotel was a relatively good deal. On balance though, I much prefer the Marriott Eaton Centre (for its central location and room quality) and the Residence Inn (because of the apartment-style accommodation). The Renaissance Skydome may be a good choice for sightseeing when the weather is ok, but if it's freezing cold, snowy, rainy or boiling hot, it's not as conveniently located as either the other downtown Marriotts (M Eaton Centre, M on Bloor, Courtyard on Yonge or Residence Inn), which are all closer to the subway system. The Marriott Eaton Centre and Residence Inn are better situated if you have business in the financial district, and the Marriott Eaton Centre and Marriott on Bloor are the best choices if you want to shop. I would stay at the Ren again, but only if the price was significantly better than the Marriott Eaton Centre and if I didn't expect unpleasant weather.

Reviews.Title: “Nice Hotel”
Reviews.Author: netgeek
Reviews.Content: Great Hotel. Staff were friendly and accomodating. The facilities were great. The room was quite spacious. The view wasnt the best (train tracks). The biggest disadvantage was the tremendously LONG walk from the elevator to the room. If you travel with those unable to walk long distances then request a room near the elevator.

Reviews.Title: “Acceptable but hardly four stars”
Reviews.Author: roadwarrior4
Reviews.Content: Used to live in Toronto for ten years and always wanted to stay at the SkyDome Hotel, but never had an occasion to do so. Flew into the Island Airport (highly recommended!) to meet up with an old friend who was in town for a few days, and needed a conveniently-located place to crash. Took a chance booking through Hotwire and ended up with this hotel for just under $100 US, everything in. A short walk from from the airport and the entertainment district, and a slightly longer walk to the financial district. The hotel is much like the stadium that it forms part of - well past its glory days but acceptable and perfectly functional. There were few staff on hand but all that we dealt with (check-in, concierge, lobby bartender) were all friendly and helpful. Room was clean and comfortable, bathroom was particularly nice - faux marble but really large, and the beds were comfortable. Note that most of the rooms look over the Canadian National rail line and during the day there is a fair amount of noise from the commuter trains (GO Transit). All in all, under the circumstances I would certainly stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “What a great location”
Reviews.Author: happyrus
Reviews.Content: The room,lobby and staff are above average.Location is one of the best!!! But the pool was below average. Water drips from the ceiling on your head constantly (no vent or fan system), some areas are actually moldy. Also, from the elevator to our room was about a 2 block walk.They keep the second set of elevators on service (would have saved us all that walking). We all agreed that if we ever get this hotel again,we would ask for a room closer to the elevator and none of us would take our swimsuits.

Reviews.Title: “Nothing wrong here.”
Reviews.Author: TakeOffEh2
Reviews.Content: Recieved a good deal on this hotel and was surprised by the room I received. Nice lobby, friendly staff.. The hallways seemed like they could use some improvement (didn't have a 'nice hotel' feel).. A good location but the self parking was a little tricky.. This hotel is even better of course if you plan to spend time around the Rogers Center, ACC or CNTower. Everything is walkable, but if you plan to spend alot of time shopping, a hotel a little more uptown could be better for you. I would recommend and definately would stay again.

Reviews.Title: “Good location, OK service”
Reviews.Author: blackrose77
Reviews.Content: The hotel is located in downtown with a walking distance to major attractions. When we arrived to the hotel we were given a small smokey room. After spending some time in the reception, they agreed to change it to something more descent. One of the cool things about it is that you can see the stadium from their restaurant, so if you're a sport fan, this is the place for you! Overall, pretty average experience.

Reviews.Title: “Don't stay here unless you want to see a game”
Reviews.Author: Yankees21
Reviews.Content: The renaissance downtown is great if you want to see a Blue Jays game. Otherwise I think you can do better. Our room smelled musty, the toilet was tricky, but everything was clean and neat. I do think that wireless internet should come free, which it doesn't at this hotel. i have stayed at small b&b's that offer free wireless internet, you're telling me that this place can't? The bar with the view of the stadium was cool and is definately worth a look. The front desk staff all were very nice and helpful w/ good restaurant suggestions and they helped us to get a reservation for lunch at the CN Tower. If I go back to Toronto, which would only be for a game, I would probably try another property.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect Location. Absolutely loved it”
Reviews.Author: gaudzrn
Reviews.Content: This was actually my first experience with hotwire. I was very nervous about it, and when i found out hat i was staying at the renaissance, I could hardly believer it. Seeing as though i was a tad naiive about the whole hotwire thing, I called the renaissance to confirm my reservation the next day, and I was told that all was good, and that my room was all set. The location itself was fantastic. They have valet parking, but to save some money, drive your own car to the underground lot. It is very easy to get to, just follow the valet's instructions. Basically, all you do is turn left coming out of the entrence, follow that road until you hit a stop sign. Turn left again and look for the sign. It is right across the street from a huge video store. I am sure you can guess which one. This hotel is situated smack dab in the heart of the city. It was a 5 minute walk to the ACC a,d a short cab drive or walk from the heart of downtown. PERFECT! We were given a city view room which was fine, as there was no events at the rogers center that weekend. I do recommend taking the rogers center tour though, as it was very interesting, and relatively cheap. We got a standard room that was absolutely perfect. The washroom itself was one of the nicest i have ever seen in a hotel. If you are looking to book a trip to enjoy the city, then look no further than this gem. Mind you, I am sure all the 4 star hotels in the city have their own pros and cons.

Reviews.Title: “Great to watch the Jays!”
Reviews.Author: lextravels
Reviews.Content: Booked a stadium view for two nights in late July. This room offers a great view of the field and you can hear everything. We really enjoyed it. The location is great too, near the waterfront, CN, and lots of restaurants just 2-3 blocks away. The room was spacious, but not luxurious. And, the hallways are long - but it is in a stadium after all. We did not care for the pool and exercise facility - run down and not very clean. We would stay again to watch a game but not for any other reason since there are so many other hotels in the area. Staff was pleasant.

Reviews.Title: “Very clean and friendly staff”
Reviews.Author: JoyceofLife
Reviews.Content: Great hotel. We stayed there when there were 3 games in town and no problem with noise. The room was very clean. The breakfast buffet was second to none. We got 2 free breakfasts a day since we had AAA. We loved how you could watch the game from inside the hotel. All you have to do is walk down to the bar and it is like being in box seats. We thought it was close to most things. The parking $20 a day is a little much. The only bad thing was that the hot tub was broken and I didn't like how you had to climb so many steps to the pool (it was really out of the way). Very friendly staff, very clean and a great choice.

Reviews.Title: “cool place”
Reviews.Author: barbiflys
Reviews.Content: I really like it. I came on a game day so I was really worried that it would be a wild, loud place. It was fine. I did sleep with earplugs though!! There are train tracks that seem to go under the hotel so you can hear them during the day--I didn't hear anything at night because I sleep with earplugs. The hotel bar is super cool because it has a press-box type view of the ballfield. The gym is gorgeous and is free!!! I would come back here in a heartbeat

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic hotel, but do fix up the pool area”
Reviews.Author: OnTraveler_8
Reviews.Content: If you are looking for a hotel in downtown Toronto close to all the biggest attractions, theatres, and shopping, the Renaissance Toronto Hotel Downtown is hard to beat. This hotel is located inside Rogers Centre, home of major league baseballâ€™s Toronto Blue Jays, adjacent to the Metro Toronto Convention Centre and the CN Tower, and close to the waterfront. Our 7th floor room was spacious, clean, well appointed, and very comfortable. It had two double beds and a separate sitting area. It faced out the front of the hotel, where we could observe people coming and going for the baseball game. Some rooms face into the ball field. Parking was under the stadium in a special hotel zone which had direct elevator access to the hotel. The food in the hotelâ€™s Arriba restaurant was outstanding. We (family of four with kids 9 and 11) ate lunch there and we all loved the food. I had the Arriba club, which came with a very well done salad. You can eat more cheaply nearby, but in my opinion, the food was fairly priced given Arribaâ€™s excellent food quality. My son and I went to the baseball game the night we were there and stopped back at the Arriba after the game for wings and a drink (I had the mango margarita). Again, both the food and the drink were excellent. The restaurant overlooks the ball field so we could observe the post game cleanup and the closing of the stadiumâ€™s retractable roof (fascinating to watch). My wife and daughter went to a show nearby and had room service for dinner, which they were also very happy with. We booked the AAA/CAA rate which came with a restaurant credit and represented good value in our opinion. This is a very fine hotel which deserves its four star rating, but it suffers from one area of neglect. The swimming pool area had dirty floors and needed tile grout repairs/cleaning. The pool area also had much visible rust on stairs, pipes, and light switch covers. There was a greenish staining on the wall going up the stairs (algae?). Pool areas are naturally humid, but this one left the windows dripping with humidity and large sheets of paint and/or plaster hung from ceiling beams. They need to add some humidity control. Finally, the pool water was cloudy and uncomfortable on the eyes, probably indicating unbalanced pool water (high pH). When I asked the staff at the nearby fitness centre how to start the whirlpool, they simply replied that the fitness staff had nothing to do with the pool (â€œnot my departmentâ€� attitude). The pool area and fitness centre staff seemed like they did not belong in this otherwise excellent hotel. The quality of the staff and facilities in all other areas was simply superb. Management should act on this one area of neglect.

Reviews.Title: “nice hotel but with very variable accomodation”
Reviews.Author: KenRoss
Reviews.Content: I've stayed at the Renaissance a few times as I was working in Toronto and we have a very good corporate rate. If you get a room at the front near the railway line it can be very noisy and the trains start early. Try to get a higher room at the rear (it's attached to the Blue Jays stadium) and it's much better. Last time I stayed there was a fire alarm (false) in the middle of the night but without even an apology from the hotel, which was a bit disappointing. I've stayed on 5 occasions over the last year and I think the standard is going down a bit. If you can get a good rate it's a great hotel but try not to pay more than $200/night.

Reviews.Title: “Serious Renovations Needed”
Reviews.Author: tassbox
Reviews.Content: The Marriott Renaissance Downtown Toronto at the Rogers Centre is neither worse nor the best hotel I have stayed at. One of the major issues I did have is the lack of elevators/lifts. There is only one bank of them. We zigged and zagged from the lifts to our room. Honestly, if were an individual with a difficulty I would not have been happy about that walk. The hotel is in dire need of serious renovations. Update some of the televisions, carpeting, paint, etc. A fresh coat of paint can do wonders. Parking. The hotel does not have a dedicated parking facility. I would recommend using the valet service. You will never find your way back. Make sure you state you do not want a room that is on the railyard side the building. You will never sleep. You will be fine at any other location. This is a great place to stay if you are attending an event at the Air Canada Centre. The facility is clean. Staff is nice.

Reviews.Title: “Not your usual hotel, but a good experience”
Reviews.Author: Happy_Harold
Reviews.Content: Booked through Priceline for a reasonable price with no idea what to expect. We were on vacation and needed another night in Toronto. Location was perfect as we were going up the CN Tower for lunch. First room offered was looking out on the train tracks, asked for another room, and oddly got another room facing the tracks, however one on 2 floors. The 3rd room offered was one in the actual Blue Jays stadium, which for a one night stay as a tourist from Europe was quite nice. Not sure what other reviewers are complaining about, saw 3 rooms, all spotlessly clean, and sizable. Staff is very friendly.Sure the decor is not new, but by definitely not the worst I have seen in 4 * properties in North America.

Reviews.Title: “Outstanding Service @ the Toronto Renaissance Downtown”
Reviews.Author: jayneoliz
Reviews.Content: I booked the Renaissance because I had business meetings on the West side of downtown TO and with a transit strike threatening I needed to be close enough to walk. I was a bit skeptical by the outside appearance of the hotel but was very pleased by the freindliness and service from the moment I got out of my car and passed it off to the valet. This is smallish hotel and doesnt have an upscale dining room, just a modern bistro. The foods quite good but priced high as you'd expect @ a hotel. My room was very nice, the furniture and finishings were all new and modern, the bed was a DREAM as they usually are @ Marriott brand hotels. I did get an upgraded room as a Silver Marriott Rwds member so not sure what the basic rooms are like. The REALLY FANTASTIC thing about this hotel was the service they offer and the genuine freindliness with which they offer it. I spend on average 25 - 40 nights a year in hotel rooms (Westin/Marriott/Hyatt usually) and have NEVER had such pleasent and helpful service. Everyone from Bell-man and front desk staff to the restaurant staff and housekeepers were absolutely fantastic. As an example, the housekeeper left me thank you notes each day for the tip I left her... that was definitely a first and I have to say that it blew me away. This is now my hotel of choice when I'm in Toronto and have already stayed another time since my first. I wasnt disappointed the second time either.

Reviews.Title: “Decent Toronto Alternative”
Reviews.Author: christianj
Reviews.Content: Just got back from a 3 night stay at the Renaissance Toronto that I won on Priceline. Considering the price I paid for the room, I give this hotel a very good rating. We really had no reason to complain about anything during our stay and the staff was very friendly and attentive. We were given a room on the 9th floor with a not so great view of the train tracks below and the city. Most of the rooms looking north would have this view as the hotel borders the train tracks on one side. Train noise was NOT an issue and the room really was very quiet considering the location of the train tracks. On a postive note, the room and the bathroom was very large. (probably one of the largest rooms I have had during my recent travels) Furnishing were relatively new and the bed was very comfortable with several pillow options provided. Housekeeping did a good job cleaning. Hallways and the lobby area were also very nicely decorated and there was free internet access provided in the lobby. The location of the hotel could be either a positive or a negative aspect of the hotel depending on why you are visiting Toronto. If you are attending an event at the Rogers Stadium or near the CN Tower you really can't beat the location. If you plan on spending time shopping and visting the Yonge and Bloor St. areas you are in for a long haul. I don't think anyone would walk from the hotel to those two shopping areas but you can take the subway from Union Station but that too is approx. a 1 mile walk away from the hotel. We are used to walking on vacations but this was IMHO the worst part of the stay at this hotel. If you get a great price like we did on Priceline then it is worth the extra distance but if I was paying full price and wanting to shop I would pick another hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Not worth the money 3 star at best.”
Reviews.Author: SteadyTraveller
Reviews.Content: To call this Hotel a four star is an insult to the other fine four star Hotels in the area. The first room that I was given was horrible. Claustrophobic, windows don't open, terrible view, the carpet was ripped and the furniture was badly banged. The cord on the internet connection was short and the set up was such that you couldnâ€™t watch television and be on the internet at the same time. It was not even a two star standards let alone a four star. After sitting on the side of the bed for half an hour imagining myself living in this room for six days I called down to complain. I was upgraded and someone promptly came by to bring me a new key. The only problem was that no one arrived to help me with my bags. I ended up dragging them down the hallway myself. The new room was larger, the view was better and the air circulation didnâ€™t feel as claustrophobic. The internet cord was still too short but at least you could see the television. The carpet was still ripped in areas and the furniture was shabby chic at best. The coffee pot was in the bathroom (eewww!) and there were no porcelain cups. Only paper cups supplied from Ikea. There was no bathrobe so I called to request one. It never arrived on the six days that I was there. The Bed was comfortable but the room was institutional and uncomfortable. The restaurant was unappealing and looked like a school cafeteria and the "validated parking" will still cost you $13 a day. There are much better Hotels in the area.

Reviews.Title: “A 3.5 Star Hotel and NOT for Everyone”
Reviews.Author: mykel67
Reviews.Content: I was booked into this hotel for one night on a business trip. I was given the choice of the Renaissance or the Royal York. I have stayed at the Royal York in the past (rooms can be small) so I thought I would give this hotel a try. Big mistake! First of all, the 4-star rating is indefensible. I have stayed at many other 4-star hotels in Toronto (Royal York, King Edward, Sutton Place, Intercontinental, Westin, Sheraton), and the Renaissance is just not up to those standards. The lobby and room decor is "1990's Carnival Cruise Ship," and the furnishings are starting to look rough around the edges. The quality of the business facilities, fitness facilities and restaurant/lounge are also not up to 4-star standards. I had the misfortune to be staying at the Renaissance during a "Monster Moto-Cross" event at the Rogers Centre. This meant that the hotel was packed with people attending that event (think Cletus and Brandine from "The Simpsons"), whose main goal was to drink as much alchohol and make as much noise as possible. Since I didn't pack my trucker hat or Wrangler jeans, I avoided the lobby bar and restaurant and ordered room service. The meal was actually quite good (green salad, shrimp pasta, wine) and not unreasonably priced. Delivery was prompt and courteous. My plans of getting an early night's sleep after dinner, however, were thwarted by the incessant drunken carousing of the Moto-Cross people, who apparently were too cheap to go out after the event ended and instead spent the night (and I mean from 10:30PM to 5:30AM) roaming the halls, going back and forth from room to room, drinking in the hallways, slamming doors and behaving like teenagers on spring break. I called the front desk to report the problem, but nothing was really done about it. Also, I had asked for and was given a room on a high floor facing the city instead of the playing field (thinking it would be quieter). This proved to be a mistake, as the noise from passing trains below was surprisingly loud. Bring earplugs! This is one of the strangest hotels I've ever stayed in. It doesn't really have anything going for it unless you are attending an event at the Rogers Centre and want to be as close as possible to the action. If you are thinking of staying here I strongly suggest you first research what events are scheduled at the Rogers Centre during your stay, for that will likely determine the make-up of the clientele. To be fair, however, I do have to say the staff was very pleasant and check-in/check-out was quick and efficient. Still, it's not a 4-star property and I would not stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Dated and in need of an urgent refurb”
Reviews.Author: georgiebest7
Reviews.Content: Stayed here for 5 nights at the brginning of March - fact it was -30 didn't help. Room 1 - dark, and smelled of cigarettes - asked to be moved - couldn't that night as the place was full for a convention - but was moved the following day. Room Two - overlooked the Skydome - nice if a ball game had to be on - the strip out from a automotive convention - not so interesting. Rooms are 1980's at best - bathrooms grubby. Service is okay. Breakfast was the best bit - great choice of everything. The 'Leisure facility' however has a lot to be desired - firstly, it's not in the hotel, well it is, but it's via the hotel that you access the local leisure club. Fitness room is okay but the pool is grubby and out dated - broken tiles etc - there were actually 2 beer cans sitting under a sun lounger the morning I went down! - steam room was so dirty I opened the door and closed it again and the shower outside was not fit for human use - I'm surprised that Starwood allow this to be used under their name. Overall - the hotel was passable, I usually stay at the Intercontinental on Front - I'll be going back there in August.

Reviews.Title: “Next door to CN Tower”
Reviews.Author: Rantin rover
Reviews.Content: We stayed here during Thanksgiving weekend when downtown Toronto was almost deserted by normal standards. We came into the city on the Airport Bus and were dropped off at the base of quite a large flight of stairs leading up to the CN Tower, the Rogers Centre (aka Skydome) and the hotel. It's a bit of a haul with luggage from the stop to the hotel entrance. However we could see why the hotel would be convenient for anyone wanting to attend the baseball since it is attached to the stadium! Large reception area with efficient staff who allocated our room quickly. Unfortunately they did not give much information about the hotel itself and we were consequently unaware of the pool on the premises despite staying for two days (we were distracted by the city attractions!). Our room, unlike many of the photos posted on the TA website, did not overlook the stadium interior. Instead we were at the front of the building looking on to the railway lines leading to Union Station! Fortunately because of Thanksgiving, traffic on the rails was limited and we didn't have trouble with the noise of trains rolling past at night. The room was a reasonable size, well furnished and decorated. The bathroom was larger than many similar standard hotels. Bed was comfortable and there was an easy chair for relaxing after a day walking around the city. Room was very comfortable overall. The dining area where we had breakfast had windows overlooking the inside of the stadium however when we were there the arena was in darkness which was a pity. On one occasion we did see the arena lit and it would be a great place to view the action if a game was in progress. Breakfast was freshly cooked to order and very well presented by friendly member of staff. It also tasted very good, although I would agree with an earlier TA posting that the fresh orange juice is too expensive. With so many places to dine in the city we ate out elsewhere at lunchtime and in the evening so cannot comment on other meals in the hotel. The dining area (where we had breakfast) was modern and fairly casual. As a base we found it quite easy to walk from the hotel to the surrounding attractions - along the waterfront - The Museum of Inuit Art was worth a visit, the CN Tower and the stores. We went up the Tower twice during our stay - on day 1 it was foggy and although the view as quite limited we had a meal in the revolving restaurant which was very good. By paying for a main course (minimum order) It meant that you didn't have to wait in a queue to get up the lift or pay for entrance to the Tower. (The cost of a main course wasn't too different to the entrance fee). However the restaurant is an experience and it's unlikely that you will want to restrict yourself to the minimum order! We returned for lunch the following day when the view was much clearer - and the food and wine still as good! The waiters are all very attentive and it is one of the more "different" dining experiences you are likely to have (unless you live in Toronto). In summary the hotel is comfortable, convenient for many downtown sights and was reasonably priced for the standard.

Reviews.Title: “Unique atmosphere and the best staff”
Reviews.Author: FauxFire
Reviews.Content: The Toronto Renaissance is a unique and special place. It is like no other hotel. Not your typical hotel in a box, the rooms have many layouts including large suites to rooms overlooking the stadium. What makes it a special place is the hotel staff. Everyone of the staff is focused on "delighting" the customer. They really care about that you are satisfied. This is a rare find in today's fast paced and high churn business environment. The resturant food is not a typical hotel quality. The menu descriptions don't do the food justice. Ask the staff for their recommendation and you will not go wrong. If you want to venture out to the downtown Toronto area it is all within walking distance. Again the staff can advise you of the best local establishments. The gym, while not exclusive to the hotel, has a lot of equipment and pool. There is cardio equipment, wieghts, and classes all available to hotel guests. Access to physio therapist and message therapist is also available. This is a great base for exploring the downtown area, catching an event at the Roger's Center, or nearby convention center.

Reviews.Title: “A place I call home”
Reviews.Author: R2ROW0720
Reviews.Content: Renaissance Downtown Toronto...hmmm...what can I say.... I have been staying here for over a year now. Pretty much every week. Most of the time I fly in on Sunday's and go home(San Antonio, TX) on Friday afternoons. It has been very challenging traveling as much as I do on this particular project. I don't think I could have been able to hang in there as good as I have without the staff and service of the Renaissance. Where do I begin.... Front desk: "Welcome home Mr. Trevino. Your bags (wkend bag I leave at hotel) are in your room and you are all set. Let us know if there is anything else you need." Resturant/bar: "Hey Art!! How are you? Hope you had a great weekend. Nice to have you back. What's for dinner?? If there is something not on the menu that we may be able to make let us know." Concierge Lounge: "Hello Art! Good to see you again. We have a nice selection for this evening. Enjoy and relax a bit." Housekeeping: (Turn down service)"Good evening Mr. Trevino. Brought you a couple of extra chocolates and waters. Have a good night." I could go on and on but I think you all get the picture. Rooms have always been clean. Fresh towels, never opened soaps, shampoos, etc. Never had a problem with cleanliness in the year that I have stayed there. Everyone I have ever been in contact with from maintenance to the GM; has always been a great experience. I am honored to say that I have made many friends and most of them are from the hotel. I not only feel like a welcomed guest but rather like family. The service, food, amenities, location have all been a great plus!!

Reviews.Title: “A mixed feeling”
Reviews.Author: cflorin
Reviews.Content: A great place to stay to enjoy games and the view from the CN tower. And the room comfort and food at the bar were good, so was the front desk service. But , as I was only one day in town and wanted a quick visit, I felt it is perhaps not the best location, you will have to walk to catch a public transport. And due to the fact it is part of the Rogers stadium building it has long ackward corridors that does not give it a cosy feeling. I stayed at the end of the corridor of the executive level with a view on concrete structures. All in all it was a good stay, but I might look for anouther location for another stay - or make sure there is a game playing.

Reviews.Title: “Very good, a bit pricey, typical high standard Marriott property”
Reviews.Author: ibookstore
Reviews.Content: We had a convention this weekend at the Metro Toronto Convention Center (South Building). It was the heart of winter, so had to walk about 5 minutes in between hotel and convention center. Not a bad walk, as you don't need to walk street-level, the pavilion area allows comfortable walking through the CN Tower, Rogers Centre, etc. The experience was very good, and I'd stay again. We got a convention rate of $96 per night, which was excellent. The room (1 king bed) was very spacious and well apportioned. The bathroom was good too. It seemed clean and tastefully decorated. The walls were a tad thin, as when ppl were walking the hallways and talking, you could hear it in your room. Service is typical Marriott high level. Front staff and others were extremely nice and hospitable. Restaurant staff were excellent, among best I've ever seen. Had a nice breakfast all 4 mornings I was there. When u order individual items, tho, watch out. A glass of OJ cost $4.00! I had their signature lemon soufle pancakes, they were heavy, not that great. But overall food was always hot and fresh. Their swimming pool, whirlpool, and sauna were great! They also have a fitness center (didn't use). I was a bit disappointed they didn't have a free Internet PC in the lobby (I've been seeing more of this lately from such a class or lower of hotel). So I think I'm spoiled to expect it. I would definitely stay in this hotel again, if I had to go to another convention here in downtown Toronto. It is extremely easy to get to/fro the QEW (right off Spadina exit).

Reviews.Title: “Great Stay & Great Staff”
Reviews.Author: MMaypo
Reviews.Content: My wife and I traveled to Toronto for a conference recently and stayed in the Downtown Renaissance as it was one of our conference hotels. I can't say enough about the great staff. I was recovering from surgery on my arm and the desk staff made a special effort to put us in a room that met my needs. On our first night we had problems getting our heat to work. The next morning I reported it to the front desk staff and the staff person on duty said she would get someone right on it and if they couldn't repair it she would move us immediately. When we returned to the hotel after some sightseeing the front desk person made a point to let us know that they had fixed the heat and in addition gave us a letter with a comp. card for various services at the hotel and a personal letter from the front desk manager with two packages of hot cider attached. Then when we got to our room we were surprised by room service with a plate of cookies & hot chocolate! What a great place - awesome views of the Roger's Center from the Bar & Restaurant. The restaurant was also a nice surprise - great food.

Reviews.Title: “Great location. Great staff. hotel to airport = $$$$$$”
Reviews.Author: egatrop
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Renaissance while attending a conference. The staff was great. They went out of their way to help a friend of mine who had booked a room at a different hotel, only to find out they had lost is reservation and were sold out. Location is good for walking around downtown Toronto, which I did a lot of. Hotel upgraded me to a suite (so reservation-less friend could share room). The suite was not a conventional suite but rather an extra large room with a sitting area. The room was clean, in good condition, and was consistent with what I'd expect at a Renaissance hotel. The only down side, and this would apply to probably any downtown lodging, is the hassle and cost to get to and from the airport. A taxi will run you around $50US. Shuttle buses will be less, but will take a long time.

Reviews.Title: “Exceeded Expectations”
Reviews.Author: Etsie
Reviews.Content: This review is biased by the absolutely best experience we have ever had, in years of traveling on business and for fun, with a front desk person at a hotel. The young lady that checked us in went so far above and beyond standard practices to insure that the start of our stay was a great experience that it needs to be recognized. This hotel chain advertises as having staff that cares about their quests - they over delivered - from the start, to the restaurant and club floor staff, everyone was friendly and helpful The hotel property itself is fine, no complaints about the rooms or public areas. Highly recomend and will stay here again if in downtown Toronto

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel for watching the game”
Reviews.Author: JLLMB79
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this hotel for one night to watch the baseball game. We got to the hotel early at 1pm and they checked us in early and upgraded us to a better room. The room had two floors, first floor had a couch, two chairs, a desk and chair and a bathroom. and a large window that opened overlooking the baseball field. The second floor had a king size bed, a bathroom and a large glass window that over looked the Rogers Center Baseball field. We had 5 people in the room to watch the game. Great view. The hotel staff was very friendly and we didn't have any problems. This room was very pricey but you get what you pay for. Very central for walking to tourist attractions.

Reviews.Title: “Unique, comfortable and well located”
Reviews.Author: RoadWarrior
Reviews.Content: We only spent one night at this hotel, but I have to say that I would be very happy to stay here again. We stayed 6 nights at the Sheraton (See review I just posted) after staying here and we wished our whole stay was at this hotel. Here's why: 1) They upgraded us to a room overlooking the baseball diamond. The Jays game had just ended when we arrived but it was still amazing to look out over the diamond and watch them clean up the field. With the windows open it was noisey but with them closed it was quiet. 2) They do NOT add extraordinary fees to their room service. As a result room service is rather affordable and the quality was excellent. 3) Their restaurant, also overlooking the diamond, is very funky and the food was quite good for breakfast. It was a nice and bright atmosphere. 4) Location is good for taking in the downtown activities. And there are plenty of dining options in the nearby area. 5) The rooms were comfortable and quiet. My one and only complaint about this hotel was the dry air in the room. I suspect the air doesn't get to circulate much being attached to the dome. We both woke up feeling like we were in the desert. But, overall, it's a great option for a tourist, visitor or even a business traveller that wants to be close to Bay Street but in a more interesting part of downtown that you will find yourself staying at with King Edward, Royal York or One King West.

Reviews.Title: “Renaissance or Four Seasons?”
Reviews.Author: Dom0446
Reviews.Content: This hotel is absolutly amazing!!!! Its connected to Rogers Centre, walking distance to GO Transit, CN Tower, Air Canada Centre, and Union Station. Better for buisness. Still, anyone would love it! Beautiful pool! The rooms are very large. We asked for a free upgrade on the room, and they gave us a suite-during a Blue Jays game when they were 'all booked'. If youre looking to go to Chinatowne, Kensington Market, or any other touristy district in Toronto, then you're probably better off with the subway-Gardiner Expressway=BAD TRAFFIC!!!!!!!!! Going to Niagara Falls from there at 1 in the afternoon is miserable traffic. 2 hours of speeding up to 60 kms an hour then to a stop. But subway is a really good choice!!!

Reviews.Title: “A great hotel for the money”
Reviews.Author: EmpireState39
Reviews.Content: I took my girlfriend to the Renaissance Marriot Hotel in Toronto. I had got the rooms off of priceline.com and it was well worth the money. I think the 340 room hotel was built in the early 1990's but is well kept up. It is located right in the Spadina Avenue area and near the street car service. You are practically right under the CN Tower and it is an impressive site. We checked in about 2pm in the afternoon on a Saturday with no wait. We had a room on the 3rd floor with all the necessities including, coffee, tea, ironing board, iron, plenty of clean towels, desk and armchair. The bed was nice king-size with plenty of pillows that was comfortable. Our room had a view of the circle where the valet parking and main entrance is. I would have liked a personal safe but the room was clean and housekeeping did a great job. We never got to check out the gym in the hotel but the Bistro bar has a great look over the stadium where the Blue Jay's play. The concierge and staff was most helpful when suggesting places to eat. One place to check out is Cora's on Wellington Ave and it is in walking distance. Otherwise they do have a continental breakfast but we never got to eat there as we were there for just two days. The hotel is far from Ontario Place and some other attractions but it was not a problem. We drove most of the time and parking is reasonably cheap in Toronto. One other bit of information for those who like to Salsa dance. Got to College Street to a place called El Rancho. There is a Salsa lesson/Dinner package for $24.99 a person. The food was great and it was a lot of fun. Parking under the stadium is about 18 dollars (CAD) a day and 25 (CAD) a dollars a day with Valet service. It was confusing were to find the garage entrance but it is located across from gate 8 and you can come and go as you please by using a ticket to clock in and out. T Bottom line a nice place to stay and well worth it.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic Hotel”
Reviews.Author: babyaim
Reviews.Content: I stayed here for a week on business and had an excellent stay. The hotel staff were helpful and polite. The rooms were great, ice machine on each floor with ice buckets in room to help yourself. Lots of choice for breakfast, plus the added bonus of looking over the pitch for the baseball game or watching the cheerleaders warming up for a football game. Pool was nice and opened early for a swim before going to the office. Would definately recommend.

Reviews.Title: “An great experience -- especially if you love baseball!”
Reviews.Author: Basicaa
Reviews.Content: Our stay was dual-purpose. To spend time with an old friend and to see the Blue Jays play. At the Renaissance Toronto Hotel Downtown we managed to combine those two activities without straying too far from the hotel. As a baseball lover, it was an incredible experience to be sitting at breakfast in the hotel restaurant while watching the roof being opened for a Blue Jays game. There is no better way to start a day, than by looking at a professional ball park. With my old friend by my side, our walk was very short to enter the ballpark itself. The only drawback to two nights at the Renaissance Toronto Hotel Downtown was the parking. It was difficult to locate and involved "taking four lefts out of the hotel driveway and looking for a sign on the right side of the street." But I must say, it was worth it. We didn't move the car for two days

Reviews.Title: “Great for a baseball fan”
Reviews.Author: gracielu
Reviews.Content: You can't get a better or more relaxing view (for $400 Canadian) than the one that you'll have from your hotel room. We loved seeing all of the pre and post game activities as well as the game itself. We had a view of the field all day long and saw television interviews, batting practice, and then the clean-up process that went on for hours after the final run was scored. My only complaint is that they don't have a special baseball room service menu. I would have thrown ample dollars at the Renaissance if they had offered me beer and hot dogs during the game. Instead I had to score a veggie dog and french fries from a street cart downstairs between innings. Staying in this hotel is a special experience for any baseball fan.

Reviews.Title: “Great for Jays Game”
Reviews.Author: deaner65
Reviews.Content: Located inside of Rogers Centre so its great for that. Way overpriced, parking $30/night. Rooms small, train tracks with constant GO train traffic under city view rooms. Overall they charge for their location and charge too much.

Reviews.Title: “baseball fan must”
Reviews.Author: SHFT54
Reviews.Content: My dad and I are huge baseball fans, so I took him here for father's day. WE LOVED IT!! The rooms are ok, not bad but not great. A little exspensive at $300+ a night. However, we loved watching batting practice and the opening and closing of the Skydome from our room. You can also watch games from the Hard Rock Cafe downstairs. The rooms are located in the Upperdeck of the outfield so the view isn't spectacular, but where else can you watch a live game from your hotel room? The window also opens and closes so you can here and smell the ballpark. Not sure I would recommend this hotel to someone who is just staying in Toronto cause I don't know what the other rooms look like.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent experience--only one small caveat”
Reviews.Author: traveladdict05
Reviews.Content: We were a bit fearful before our arrival at the Renaissance, as we had booked (for the first time) through priceline.com and had bid $60 US for a minimum 3 star in downtown Toronto. When I got the Renaissance, I was delighted when I saw the pictures of the hotel on their website, but I was quite convinced that I would be given an absolutely terrible room (since I was paying less than half of the rate offered on Expedia). When we arrived at the Renaissance, the hotel was every bit as nice as the pictures on the website. The service at the desk was very pleasant. Even better, our mouths fell open when we walked into our room, as they had given us a very large, very nice room. It had a king bed and a seperate sitting area with a couch and 2nd tv. One of the biggest non-suite hotel rooms I have ever seen. It was beautifully decorated and spotlessly clean. Definitely not their worst room! The view was the only thing not impressive--it overlooked the train tracks. However, we were quite pleased to get a "city-view" and not a view of the field. And we did not hear any noise from the trains. The location of the hotel was great--close to st. lawrence market, and close to Queen Street, which is my preferred street in Toronto. The best breakfast I have ever had in Toronto I discovered on this trip--Le petit dejeuner restaurant on King St. E near the corner of Jarvis. Absolutely awesome waffles and eggs benedict! And just a couple of blocks from the St. Lawrence market for browsing afterward. Caveat: The only negative experience we had at this hotel was when we pulled up to the front of the hotel, we were given very bad and incomplete directions from one of the valet parking people as to how to find the self-parking entrance . (Valet parking is $25, self-parking is $17) The entrance to the self-parking is relatively far from the entrance to the hotel but would have been simple to find had he had given us better directions. Because of his crappy directions, we circled around for 10 minutes through very busy city streets before finding it--the sign indicates it is the parking for the Rogers Centre but does not mention the hotel . You think he would have mentioned that! Once you drive in, there is a section devoted to parking for the hotel and an elevator takes you up to the hotel lobby.

Reviews.Title: “Watch your credit card!”
Reviews.Author: cober6711
Reviews.Content: I stayed here because I needed to get away from home for a night, and I won this hotel for a $58 bid on priceline. The hotel was pretty good, though I'd advise asking for a room close to the elevator; room 397 was a VERY long way from the elevator. The room was very clean, and huge, and the bed was great. However, the day following check out, my credit card was charged $68.40, with absolutely no explanation as to why. I was told that this charge would be refunded, however they have yet to do so (after over 10 days!), and I'm now having to call MasterCard to dispute the charge.

Reviews.Title: “Nice, yet nothing spectacular”
Reviews.Author: bheikoop
Reviews.Content: This was my first stay at a Renaissance hotel and not only would I visit this hotel again, but I would not hesitate to recommend this hotel. The staff was very pleasant, starting from the valet attendants to the front desk associates. I booked the trip on Hotwire, which rates the Renaissance Toronto Hotel Downtown as a "4 Star". My overall impression was not that of a 4 star, rather, a 3/3.5. I do not have any major complaints, however, some minor flaws in the hotel that if worsened, could lead to a rather disappointing trip. The rooms could use some slight upgrades and a little elbow grease. While my room was not awful, I am certain there are better rooms at the hotel, and a hotel of rooms in the condition of mine, would not rate as a "4 Star". The front desk associate was very helpful in suggesting I watch the ballgame from the Hotel lounge/bar "Arriba". This is something I would do again and suggest to any visitor that isn't 100% enthused with baseball. Overall, I do not have any real complaints. It is a hotel I would stay at again, but with moderate expectations. I am not certain I would pay the weekday list price for this room.

Reviews.Title: “A nice hotel but watch out for the off-season”
Reviews.Author: cdn1939
Reviews.Content: This property is a nice hotel typical of a 3 or 3.5 star rating. Its location is ideal if you're attending an event at the Rogers Centre (formerly SkyDome) or in the general area. One general warning is that the hotel offers a group of rooms with stadium views. I am sure these are fabulous rooms during baseball season, however, during the off-season these rooms seem dark because the dome is closed during the winter. Also, I was there during the car show and while it was unique to watch the crowds for awhile, the noise and dim lighting were not ideal. Again, I think if you are staying there to get a view of a particular event then this would not be a problem. Otherwise, the highlights of this property were definitely the staff - the desk staff were always helpful and pleasant. Also the self-parking is reasonable at about $16/night with in/out privileges. A few problems include the fact the room was sprayed with a strongly scented deodorizer that was off-putting. Also, the room itself was sparse and showed signs of wear and age - not typical of the Renaissance properties which often feature distinctive design and furniture. Overall, this is a decent property that would benefit from some upgrades.

Reviews.Title: “Not the best”
Reviews.Author: piink
Reviews.Content: We stayed for two nights here at the end of our holiday and I am glad we did not stay for any longer. It is not a bad hotel but does not compare to others we stayed in in Canada. As other reviews state you have to realise it is wrapped around sports centre so expect to have to walk a fair way to your room. We were upgraded to a Jacuzzi bath room which was great, although not the cleanest bathrooms and starting to get a bit worn. But the bed was huge and in an enormous room. Overlooked railway tracks so not great but hey we didnt spend that much time in the rooms anyway. If you are a ice hockey fan then there is the Wayne Gretzky restaurante just a few mins walk from the hotel, which serves great cheap food and drinks and atmosphere is great esp on a match night. We ended up there for dinner on both nights of our stay. Hotel is also very close to the CN Tower which you have to go up, I hated the glass floor but glass does not cover the whole floor so you dont have to walk on it if you dont want. The hotel health centre is not very good, didnt try the gym but the pool was okay, the whirlpool did not whirl and was not that warm and the sauna was a bit dirty, went in it once and then decided by jacuzzi bath in my room was by far better. The whole health suite was grubby and could do with a makeover. In comparison to London hotels of a similar rating then this was nice but am sure there are probably nicer hotels to stay at in Toronto.

Reviews.Title: “Well situated and clean”
Reviews.Author: SteveDCormier
Reviews.Content: My son and I spent from January 2nd to 6th at the Renaissance, as we wanted to see a Raptors game. We were pleased with our experience.
